verses.text: You must teach what is in accord with sound doctrine.

rsbNotes.title: Titus 2
rsbNotes.text: 2:1–15 Paul now turns to the kinds of things which Titus, in contrast with the false teachers, ought to teach and concludes with a meditation on the grace of God.

rsbNotes.title: Titus 2:1
rsbNotes.text: 2:1 sound doctrine. See note 1:9.

verses.text: Teach the older men to be temperate, worthy of respect, self-controlled, and sound in faith, in love and in endurance.

rsbNotes.title: Titus 2:2–6
rsbNotes.text: 2:2–6 See 1 Tim. 5:1, 2.

rsbNotes.title: Titus 2:2
rsbNotes.text: 2:2 sober-minded. The quality of sober-mindedness dominates Paul’s advice in this section (vv. 4–6, 12; 1:8 and note).

verses.text: Likewise, teach the older women to be reverent in the way they live, not to be slanderers or addicted to much wine, but to teach what is good.

rsbNotes.title: Titus 2:3
rsbNotes.text: 2:3 teach what is good. Probably, as the next verse suggests, in the sense of their manner in the home.

verses.text: Then they can train the younger women to love their husbands and children,

rsbNotes.title: Titus 2:4
rsbNotes.text: 2:4 train. That is, “bring them to their senses.” This is a verbal form of the adjective translated “sober-minded” (v. 2) and “self-controlled” (v. 5) throughout this section. Paul probably has in mind the problems that some of the younger widows encountered at Ephesus (1 Tim. 5:11–13).

verses.text: to be self-controlled and pure, to be busy at home, to be kind, and to be subject to their husbands, so that no one will malign the word of God.
Similarly, encourage the young men to be self-controlled.

rsbNotes.title: Titus 2:5
rsbNotes.text:
2:5 self-controlled. Lit. “sober-minded” (vv. 2, 4, 6, 12; 1:8 note).

working at home. Or, “busy at home.” Contrast the behavior of some of the younger widows at Ephesus (1 Tim. 5:13).

submissive. See note 1 Tim. 2:11.

that the word of God may not be reviled. Paul’s overriding concern throughout this section is that the behavior of Christians reflect positively on the gospel (vv. 8, 10).

verses.text: In everything set them an example by doing what is good. In your teaching show integrity, seriousness
and soundness of speech that cannot be condemned, so that those who oppose you may be ashamed because they have nothing bad to say about us.

rsbNotes.title: Titus 2:7
rsbNotes.text:
2:7 be a model. Paul gives similar counsel to Timothy (1 Tim. 4:12 note).

good works. One of Paul’s main themes in this letter from here on (v. 14; 3:1, 8, 14).

verses.text: Teach slaves to be subject to their masters in everything, to try to please them, not to talk back to them,

rsbNotes.title: Titus 2:9
rsbNotes.text: 2:9 Slaves. Paul gives instructions to slaves in Eph. 6:5–8; Col. 3:22–25; and 1 Tim. 6:1, 2.

verses.text: and not to steal from them, but to show that they can be fully trusted, so that in every way they will make the teaching about God our Savior attractive.

rsbNotes.title: Titus 2:10
rsbNotes.text: 2:10 adorn the doctrine of God. See note on v. 5.

verses.text: For the grace of God that brings salvation has appeared to all men.
It teaches us to say "No" to ungodliness and worldly passions, and to live self-controlled, upright and godly lives in this present age,

rsbNotes.title: Titus 2:11–14
rsbNotes.text: 2:11–14 These verses provide the theological basis for the practical instructions given in vv. 2–10.

rsbNotes.title: Titus 2:11
rsbNotes.text:
2:11 the grace of God. The unmerited compassion of God.

has appeared. That is, in Jesus Christ (3:4, 6; 2 Tim. 1:10).

bringing salvation. God’s purpose in extending grace to sinners is their salvation (3:4–7; 2 Tim. 1:9).

all people. All types of people, regardless of gender, age, or social class are in view (vv. 2–10; 1 Tim. 2:1–6).

verses.text: while we wait for the blessed hope--the glorious appearing of our great God and Savior, Jesus Christ,

rsbNotes.title: Titus 2:13
rsbNotes.text:
2:13 our blessed hope, the appearing of the glory. The Second Coming (1 Tim. 6:14; 2 Tim. 4:1, 8). See “Hope” at Heb. 6:18.

our great God and Savior Jesus Christ. This is one of the clearest affirmations in the New Testament of the deity of Christ.

verses.text: who gave himself for us to redeem us from all wickedness and to purify for himself a people that are his very own, eager to do what is good.

rsbNotes.title: Titus 2:14
rsbNotes.text:
2:14 who gave himself for us. That is, on the cross. Paul follows with two aspects of the work of Christ.

redeem us from all lawlessness. Paul’s first point focuses on the individual: Christ paid the price necessary to free people from their sins (Matt. 20:28; Mark 10:45; 1 Tim. 2:6; 1 Pet. 1:18, 19).

purify for himself a people for his own possession. Paul’s second point focuses on the church: Christ purifies individuals from their sins (Heb. 9:14; 1 John 1:7, 9) so that together they might constitute a people special to Him (Ezek. 37:23). On Christ purifying the church, see Eph. 5:25–27.

zealous for good works. See note on v. 7.

verses.text: These, then, are the things you should teach. Encourage and rebuke with all authority. Do not let anyone despise you.

rsbNotes.title: Titus 2:15
rsbNotes.text:
2:15 exhort and rebuke. An appropriate summation of the contrasting aspects of Paul’s charge to Titus in vv. 2–10 and 1:10–16.

with all authority. That is, as Paul’s representative.

Let no one disregard you. See v. 8; 1 Tim. 4:12.
